Posts.Content: CCrill wrote: I had a complete hysterectomy four years ago at the age of 33.  About a year after, I was told I had fibercystic breast tissue.  The left breast is much worse than the right.  It is sore, more dense and now I am experiencing itching around the nipple area.  I saw my doctor and she said everything looked fine, but wants me to get a diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound to make sure that there isn't something hiding behind the density that she can't feel.  I have had this checked before, I feel silly because I know it probably isn't serious, but I feel like I need to be pro active.  I had my annual mammogram seven months ago and other than the density it was normal. I also sometimes feel like that left nipple is "wet", but don't see any discharge on my bra or shirt, crazy, I know.  I go tomorrow for the tests.  I hate the mammograms because I am very large chested and it is very uncomfortable for me.  The density seems to get worse each mammogram. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Fibercystic Breast tissue-Left breast always causing me trouble. CCrill CCrill

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2014 07:15PM CCrill wrote: Hi SlowDeepBreaths, Was your cancer hidden behind the density?  Sometimes I think that because I am young I am being brushed off.

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2014 01:30PM CCrill wrote: Hi, thanks for your reply! I definitely am glad technology has improved.  How was your tumor diagnosed?  I am waiting on the ok from the doctor to proceed with the MRI.  To all the ladies who have replied, what are your thoughts on having benign cysts, fibroids, etc removed?  I have a benign lymph node growing into the side of that breast, but nobody has ever told me that it needs to be removed.  As I said before, my mother in law had very dense breasts and her tumor was hiding behind all of that.

Posts.Title: Fibercystic Breast tissue-Left breast always causing me trouble. CCrill CCrill

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2014 12:46PM CCrill wrote: My mother in law was 51 when she was diagnosed with breast cancer, stage 2.  She had very dense breast tissue and therefore they did not find her cancer early.  It eventually spread to her bones.  It wasn't until they finally did an MRI that they discovered it.  I think that is why I am so proactive about it, even though it isn't in the bloodline and she was older than me, seeing what she went through made me decide I wasn't taking any chances.
